en.short: Forum Shopping (bad) <-> Main establishment established by rules (good)
en.title: Choosing your own jurisdiction weakens data protection.
en.description: If companies can "designate" their main establishment, they will choose the weakest possible data protection environment, which will in turn weaken data protection.

en.short: Less (bad) <-> more (good) rules for pseudonymous data
en.title: Less rules for pseudonimous data weakens data protection.
en.description: A low bar for "pseudonym data" is a giant loophole in the law, because it is easy to de-anonymize data.

en.short: Less (bad) <-> more (good) limits for sensitive personal data
en.title: More limits result in stronger data protection.
en.description: Highly sensitive personal data (like sexual orientation, genetic data or data concerning health) is not needed for every purpose.

en.title: The higher the penalties, the better for data protection.
en.description: If the law is breached, there should be effectve fines.

en.short: Less (bad) <-> more (good) rights for comsumer organisations
en.title: Enforcement by consumer organisations strengthens data protection
en.description: Normal users have no time and money to sue e.g. Google.

en.short: limiting (bad) <-> expanding (good) the power of <abbr title="Data Protection Officer">DPO</abbr>s
en.title: Limiting Independence of "Data Protection Officers"
en.description: The "Data Protection Officer" should be a form of internal control. They have to be independent, and protected against retaliation.

en.short: Easy (bad) <-> hard (good) to obtain consumer consent
en.title: Meaningful "consumer consent" strengthens data protection
en.description: Companies should not be able to force users to a "freely given" consent to data processing.

en.short: Hard (bad) <-> easy (good) access to data somebody has stored about you
en.title: Being able to see the data collected strengthens data protection
en.description: The right of citizens to obtain a copy of their personal data  - in an "electronic form" etc - is essential.

en.title: "Profiling" is bad for data protection
en.description: The negative effects of "profiling" have to be limited with rules who can profile in the first place and how citizens can prevent companies from doing it.

en.short: Less (bad) <-> more (good) limits for cloud providers
en.title: Limiting the duties of "cloud" providers weakens data protection
en.description: EU citizens’ data should be secure independent of where and by whom it is stored.

en.title: "Data Minimization" strengthens data protection
en.description: Essentially every "bit" that is not necessary must be deleted, or not be stored in the first place.

en.short: Less (bad) <-> more (good) rules for sharing data
en.title: Being able to share Data easily is bad for data protection
en.description: A company should not be able to share citizens’ data with anyone that has a "legitimate interest" in them (which is in fact anyone in the world).
